title: New T'bird release - I cannot view my my emails in the manner that has worked so well for over 20 years
creator: ainut
content:
I positively DESPISE the new Thunderbird. 1) I cannot view my my emails in the manner that has worked so well for over 20 years. 2) In order to see the new emails, I have to scroll past 3 billion old emails to see the newest ones. 3) Even worse, if I don't delete the current viewed email, I have to scroll to the left, past the 3 billion old emails (that I have to save and have current, to get to the "origin" so that I can click on the NEXT ONE TO READ!. 4) I can no longer get T'bird to throw away 'banned' senders that were previously automatically moved to the 'junk' pile without my having to waste time dealing with their ads yet AGAIN. 5) Can't seem to get emails sorted by date, subject or what have you like before.

I want my old T'bird interface back.

David Merchant (<redacted>@hiwaay.net & <redacted>@hiwaay.net)
metadata: ;useragent:Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Ubuntu; Linux x86_64; rv:138.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/138.0

title: Trying to recover old Address Book in Thunderbird
creator: rdnorrod
content:
I just did a Windows 10 clean install and re-installed Thunderbird (ver 138.0). Because of a foul-up with File History, my most recent backups did not include the Appdata directory. I found a very old backup (2018) and copied the TB profile from that, overwriting the new TB profile folder. That did recover messages, local folders, etc. prior to 2018, but the Address Book still has no entries. There appears to be some data in the old history.mab and abook.mab files that came over, but no contacts appear in any of the address books in the new installation.

Despite the age, it would be of some use to recover the ca. 2018 address book. Suggestions?

content:
I have installed the "Start with Inbox" extension. I am trying to find the correct setting that selects the the top message in my message list and displays the contents in the message pane (reading pane). I've tried several of he settings. Here is the list of options.

Select and put the focus on: the last message.* the newest message.** the newest unread message.** the oldest unread message.** the inbox folder in the folder tree.

       message)

title: Moving Thunderbird Profiles to Onedrive
creator: GayzeN
content:
I have been using Thunderbird since its first incarnation. I currently monitor (some for non-profits, some my own) five email accounts in Thunderbird. They are all IMAP accounts. However, my own main account also has an extensive system of local folders that adds up to about 12GB of data, and probably over 100 folders (don't ask; it was necessary until I retired last year, but I need to keep all of those saved emails, as I still access them frequently).

I've searched the forums and have found good information on moving Tbird to a new computer, but that's not what I'm looking for. Chances are what I need is here, and I've missed it, so please forgive if I'm rehashing old questions.

Currently, my Thunderbird profile and folders are stored on my C: drive, as is the default. I have been manually backing them up several times a week (for years) to OneDrive, because I can't afford to lose everything if my laptop decides to bite the dust. Using that method, I've successfully moved the setup to a new computer several times. I'm not sure why simply redirecting the setup to a different location on the same system has been a bugbear for me. ::smile::

It would be much less labor-intensive if I can simply point Thunderbird to the OneDrive files so they are always up-to-date and "there," should I need to make a computer change again.

Note, that I am not looking to access the Tbird installation with multiple computers.

I have tried (and failed) to do this in the past. Either my emails are not there, my address books are missing, or a variety of other issues that indicate an incomplete move.

I'm ready to give it another shot, and I appreciate your time and help.
metadata: ;useragent:Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/135.0.0.0 Safari/537.36

title: Thunderbird Contacts versus iPhone Contacts.
creator: b5sgq4wgh4
content: I have a iPhone 16 and in Contacts you are given the option to add a phone type. So instead of Home or Cell you can add a custom tag such as Shop or Home2 in the event one has two home phones. The problem is Thunderbird only has Six options for Phone Type. There is no custom. If I go on iCloud and I have a phone number set a Custom and named it Shop there is not a issue as both the phone and icloud support Custom tags. How does a person add that phone number into Thunderbird since Custom Tags are not a option? I even exported my data from Thunderbird to a VCard and went into Systools Split and Merge and it does not support Custom tags either. Systools does however give a few more options than Thunderbird, but none that I am aware of are configurable. I thought VCard was supposed to be a industry standard and the same across all platforms and clients? NOT SO.

title: Using profile file to move to new server. Not working
creator: lnbjohnson
content:
Trying to move IMAP Thunderbird emails to a new server. I used WHM to move TB and a lot of other files to the new server about 4 months ago. Before switching the DNS I downloaded the TB profile. Changed the DNS. I also reinstalled TB. After the DNS change took effect I replaced the profile. The accounts, passwords, and folders came in fine.

The problem is that TB shows emails from 4 months ago, but not newer emails. I can send and receive emails with either the old or new DNS. Emails send today show up fine (so I have very old emails, and brand new emails. Just nothing in between. There are 4 email accounts with years of saved emails (16 gb)

I have tried: Using TB import tool to install both the Thunderbird profile folder and the ~~~default-release folder. Tried to do this manually just replacing the files. Also tried setting up 2 email accounts (old and new server) for the same account. I could not get this to load the old emails. If I change the DNS back to the old server and wait; eventually I can access the current emails, so they are still there.

When the DNS is pointed to the new server, and I drop in the old server profile file, sometimes there is a flash where current emails show, and then are erased. It sort gives me the impression that the profile file is inserting the emails locally, but the IMAP server is removing the emails because they are not on the server. I am tempted to go to the new server and delete one of the email accounts and re-install it, but I would like some advice before I do this.
metadata: ;useragent:Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/135.0.0.0 Safari/537.36

title: migrated from win 10 to linux but am missing a large amount of contacts from cardbook

content:
my old windows 10 comp died so now have a zorin linux computer I am setting up. Took the win 10 drives out of the old box and can usb connect them to the new linux box so I can search for files . Copied over the old profile folder and set up the new thunderbird linux install fine.

Then located the 5 groups of address books I use for my home business, vendors, subs, customers etc. they were regularly updated on a NAS, where I found recent version.

All imported fine except the largest of the group, customers, been in business over 40 years so have a lot. That import only had one item and was much smaller in size than the others which makes no sense since it has the most contacts.

Question: where else can I look on the win 10 directories to find those missing files?

Any and all suggestions would be greatly appreciated, thanks for taking the time to read this.
